title: That Time I Tried (And Failed) To Become A Rebel
html:
Homepage
Homepage

That Time I Tried (And Failed) To Become A Rebel

Those who can’t get good grades, try to change their image

Kyrie Gray
Apr 1

From the moment I entered kindergarten I was a good student. The smell of freshly sharpened pencils made me jittery with excitement. An unhealthy need to prove myself academically meant that I was destined to be a model student.

Note that I did not claim to be brilliant. For I was not one of those children who just understood how to construct block bridges right away. Nor could I pronounce the W sound to save my life (or my mother’s sanity).

Yet I was well behaved. I toed that invisible line for fear of being labeled as a troublemaker by my teachers.

I shared when other students desired the my toys.

I diligently practiced story problems in which farmers were suspiciously specific about the amount of produce they shared. Also, what farmer ONLY has 7 apples? No doubt the farmers and candy store owners from those equations were secretly laundering money and some brave mathematics textbook writer was trying to let the world know.

My oral reports were awe-inspiring. This had less to do with my public speaking skills and more to do with the fact that 75% of an elementary school grade is based on “dazzle.” My mom’s scrapbooking room kept me stocked in glitter and crazy scissors, meaning I got an easy A.

The external validations that I was not an idiot meant a great deal to me at the time. Grades were important. Not like “wear-heels-to-a-black-tie-function” important.

No.

Grades were “we-need-to-save-that-water-because-we-don’t-know-when-we-will-get-off-this-island” important.

Bad grades had consequences. Or at least that’s what I assumed.

The problem was my expectations for high grades begun to outstrip my talent for math. When my easily distracted nature was factored in, it didn’t take a genius to figure out a storm was brewing. And that storm hit my senior year in the form of pre-calculus.

Looking back I think it’s safe to say that it was my study technique, which generally consisted of trying to memorize formulas while simultaneously watching Gilligan’s Island reruns at four in the morning, was probably inadvisable. Still, I was disillusioned.

Since my perfect grades were gone what was the point? Nothing mattered. All my hard work was gone in a puff of red ink.

I made a life-changing decision.

I decided to be a rebel.

So began my life of playing hooky during fourth period. Most kids walked two blocks to the bus terminal and smoked. But I didn’t like cigarettes. Also, being quite introverted, the thought of hanging around strangers made me nervous. As a result, my choices of locations to be rebellious were severely limited.

Sometimes I went to the library.

Or hey, I didn’t care, I might walk even farther to the Jamba Juice. Who needed to know about the kings of England when you could get jacked on a kale sugar smoothie?

If I wanted to be really bad, I’d go to the duck pond and feed the animals. That sign that warned pond-goers to refrain from such actives? Screw that! Rebels didn’t read signs written by THE MAN.

On a side note, I might be partly to blame for the explosive population of the invasive nutria rat.

This phase lasted a semester. It wasn’t the teachers who dissuaded my behavior, although once or twice a couple did try to hint that I was well on my way to being a dropout.

It was the children’s librarian, who put a stop to my life of being bad. Turned out she didn’t believe my cleverly crafted stories. Which is crazy. I played Oregon Trail enough times to know how serious an outbreak of cholera could be. Why wouldn’t a school be shut down for a week?

So I returned to the halls of academia, continuing to underwhelm my teachers for 5 years.

Thanks for reading! Follow Intrepid for more doodled stories and check some other ones you might have missed below:

How a board game taught me that I will do crazy things for lovemedium.com

    Bravely writing and doodling ahead
